https://prez.dev/description.@value: Geotechnical investigations performed to obtain information on the physical and mechanical properties of soil and rock around a site to design earthworks and foundations for proposed structures and for repair of distress to earthworks and structures caused by subsurface conditions.
The subject is an instance of a class.
The defininition of the subject resource.
An idea or notion; a unit of thought
An alternative lexical label for a resource

skos:closeMatch is used to link two concepts that are sufficiently similar that they can be used interchangeably in some information retrieval applications. In order to avoid the possibility of 'compound errors' when combining mappings across more than two concept schemes, skos:closeMatch is not declared to be a transitive property
A statement or formal explanation of the meaning of a concept
A note about the past state/use/meaning of a concept
Relates a resource (for example a concept) to a concept scheme in which it is included
The preferred lexical label for a resource, in a given language
Relates a concept to the concept scheme that it is a top level concept of

The primary purpose for which a borehole was drilled or any secondary purpose that the borehole may acquire during its lifecycle. The vocabulary focuses on drilling purposes within the resources industry, with a focus on terminology as applied in the Geological Survey of Western Australia (GSWA) databases. Some terms covered by jurisdictional legislation are highlighted in the provenance field. Variations in terminology within definitions (i.e. usage of borehole, well and wellbore) stem from usage in different sectors of the resources industry, but for the purpose of this vocabulary are considered to be equivalent. In the context of this vocabulary, the term fluid energy refers to sources such as gas, petroleum and geothermal, as covered by the Petroleum Legislation Amendment Act 2024, and is exclusive of mineral sources of energy (e.g. coal, uranium).

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: Geotechnical or engineering drilling is carried out to determine soil and rock characteristics in order to facilitate infrastructure and mine planning. It includes the collection of rock and soil samples to determine physical properties (e.g. strength, hardness, fracture and fault frequency) for geotechnical analysis and to identify where unsafe rock or soil conditions could trigger a structural collapse or cause a hazardous scenario during, for example, an earthquake or flooding event. Geotechnical drilling is conducted to assess the potential construction sites of both above and below ground projects, including but not limited to buildings and storage structures, dams, bridges, roads, wharves and other civil works, and below surface projects such as tunnels and shafts (including all open pits and underground mining areas), access or inspection holes, or to facilitate installation of monitoring equipment (e.g. tiltmeters/inclinometers, piezometers and other sensors). Geotechnical work can overlap with environmental drilling on sites where there is a potential for environmental hazards.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#hist.@value: Modified from Australian Drilling Industry Association (2020; The Drilling Manual, Sixth Edition).

Borehole drilled to investigate the geotechnical properties of the strata and provide samples for mechanical testing.
